titleStmt.title: იერუსალიმის ჯვრის მონასტრის აღაპები - Jerusalem Cross Monastery, Jer_24

editionStmt.edition: Electronic edition based on printed source

monogr.author: Elene Meṭreveli
monogr.title: Masalebi ierusalimis kartuli ḳoloniis isṭoriisatvis (XI-XVII ss.)

msContents.summary: Liturgical records (Synaxarion) containing commemorative services and prayers from the Cross Monastery

projectDesc.p: Electronic edition of Georgian liturgical records with structured markup of personal names, dates, and manuscript references

editorialDecl.p: Abbreviations resolved wherever possible. Editorial additions in square brackets.

namespace.name: http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0

Page break with manuscript and edition references
Line break with manuscript and edition references
Segment of text with a specific function (e.g., formula, curse, ritual)

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა ვ
გაუჩინეთ ჩუენ, ჯუარის მამამან ნიკიფო
რემ, ეპისკოპოსმან თეოდოსემ და სრულად
კრებულთა, მეფეთ მეფესა ალექსანდრეს და დედო
ფალთა დედოფალს ნესტან-დარეჯანს აღაპი და
მოსახსენებელი. და ვინცა მოშალოს, იგიმცა
მოიშლების.
item.note: Foundation of an agape and memorial prayer by the Cross Monastery clergy for King of Kings Aleksandre and Queen of Queens Nestan-Darejan.
Nikifore (Cross Father), Teodose (Bishop), King Aleksandre, Queen Nestan-Darejan.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა ... ზ
ქ{რისტე}. ამასვე დღესა პანაშჳდი
მიქაელ ქუთათე
ლისა
საუკუნოჲ, გარდაიჴდებოდეს დაუკლებე
ლად, და ვინცა დააკლოს, ღმერთმან ჰკითხოს.
item.note: Eternal and inalienable requiem service established for Mikael, the high clergyman of Kutaisi.
Agape meal established for Mikael of Abkhazia.

item.p:
ამასვე დღესა აღაპი და პანაშჳდი
ობედ ებნი
სურურ ებნუ სალამ და გაუჩინეთ პანაშჳდი და
წირვაჲ. შემოგუწირა რამლას მისი სახლი მეტო
ქედ სამლოცველად მისთა მშობელთათჳს და
მისისა მეღლისათჳს. ღმერთმან ჰკითხოს, ვინცა შეცვალოს.
item.note: Foundation of services (agape, requiem, liturgy) by Obed ibn Surur ibn Salam, who donated his house in Ramla as a metochion for the commemoration of his parents and wife.
Obed ibn Surur ibn Salam (donor), his parents, his wife.
Donation of a house in Ramla.
Donor has an Arabic name, indicating interaction between Georgian and local Christian communities.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა ჱ
მე უღირსი მამა ციდაშვილი სიმონა
ვარ ამისი მოწმე. და ჩემსა მამობას შიგან
იქმნა ამისი ძმობა და ამისთა აღმასრულე
ბელთა ღმერთმან მომადლოს კურთხე
ვაჲ საუკუნოჲ და ჩუენ გაუჩინეთ საძმო
სახლი ოცილობელი და ჰქონდეს ყოველსა .
item.note: Witness statement by Father Simona Tsidashvili confirming the establishment of a brotherhood, which occurred during his time as Father, and the donation of a disputed house.
This entry is a legal/administrative confirmation of the preceding foundation by Obed.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა ჱ
მე ზოსიმე (მოძღუა)რი მოწამე ვარ (მა)მისა
და ძმათა ბრძანებისა.
item.note: A second witness statement by Zosime the Teacher, confirming the act by the order of the Father and the brothers.

item.p:
სეკდენბერსა ჱ. აღაპი და წირვაჲ
მანდა\ტურთ
უხუცესისა ბექასათჳს , რაოდენცა ხუცესი
იყოს, ჟამი უწირონ.
item.note: Agape and liturgy for Beqa, the Mandaturt-Ukhutsesi (Chief of the Bodyguard), with a special instruction that all available priests should celebrate the office for him.
Mandaturt-Ukhutsesi was a high-ranking court official, chief of the imperial guard or ushers.
A special provision mandates the participation of all available priests, highlighting the high status of the commemorated person.

item.p:
სეკდენბერსა ჱ. წირვა და აღაპი საუკუნო
მეფისა დისა ულუმპიასი , შეუნდვნეს ღმერთმან.
item.note: Eternal liturgy and agape meal established for Ulempea, sister of the king.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა ჱ
ამასვე დღესა წირვაჲ და აღაპი
დავით მე
ფისა , შეუნდვნეს ღმერთმან.
item.note: Liturgy and agape meal established for King Davit.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა ჱ
ამასვე დღესა აღაპი საუკუნოი პანაშჳდითა და,
რავდენიცა ხუცესი იყოს, წირვითა და ყოველთა სიწმიდისა გარდმოსვენებათა
იოვანე და
კახა
ბერ... ჩამოლოცვითა . შემოსწირა მონასტერსა
ორი ათასისა დრამა დიდსა დაჭირებასა შინა
მონასტრისასა ... რაჲსა ...სა მოღებითა, ვინ
ცა შეცვალოს, კანონსა ქუეშე იყოს და კ
შ̃სა ს.
item.note: An eternal agape with requiem and liturgy by all available priests was established for Iovane and Kakhaber, who donated 2000 drama to the monastery during a time of great hardship.
Service to be performed by all available priests, with veneration of all relics, indicating high importance.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა თ
ქ{რისტე}.
სალამ ებნი ფარა , დარი შემოგუწირა რამლას
და ჩუენ გაუჩინეთ სეკდემბერსა თ აღაპი
და შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან.
item.note: Salam ibn Fara donated a house/granary in Ramla, and in return, the monastery established an agape for him on September 9th.

item.p:
სეკდენბერსა თ. აღაპი და პანაშჳდი
დიოფალ
თა დიოფალისა თამარ-ყოფილისა თომაიდასი .
მისი წყალობაჲ დიდი მოვიდა, და ვინცა შე
ცვალოს და არ გარდაიჴადოს, კრულმცა არს
ღმრთისა მადლითა, და გამათავებელნი ღმერ
თმან აკურთხნეს, ა{მი}ნ.
item.note: Agape and requiem established for the Queen of Queens Tamar, who later took the name Thomaida, in return for her great gift. The entry includes a curse for non-compliance and a blessing for fulfillers.
Indicates that Queen Tamar took the religious name Thomaida, likely upon entering a convent.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა თ
ამასვე დღესა აღაპი
მიქაელ ბედიელისა და
წირვაჲ და აღაპი საუკუნოჲ
მიქაელ გონგ
ლიბაჲს ძისა ბედიელისაჲ
პანაშჳდითა, შეუნდ
ვენ ღმერთმან.
item.note: A dual memorial for Mikael Bedieli (Bishop of Bedia) on the same day: a simple agape, and a more comprehensive eternal liturgy, agape, and requiem for him, identified also by his patronymic 'son of Gonglibay'.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა ია
ამასვე დღეს პანაშჳდი
აბუსერისძისა სი
დედრისა ბორენასა , შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან.
item.note: Requiem service for Borena, the mother-in-law of the noble Abuserisdze.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა იგ
ამას დღესა ენკენიასა გავაჩინეთ აღაპი
გრიგოლ მშჳდაისათჳს და
მიცვალებულთა
მისთათჳს . ერთი ხუცესი ეწირვებოდის და
კარგი აღაპი გარდაიჴდებოდის. და ვინცა ესე
ერთობ კრებულისა ნებსით დაწერილი და
განწესებული აქციოს და შეცვა)ლოს, შე-მცა-
ც{}ვლილ არს სჯულისაგან ქრისტეანეთაჲსა, და
ჰრისხავსმცა მამა, ძე და სული წმიდაჲ და
პატიოსანი ჯუარი, რომელსა ზედა ჯუარს
ეცუა უფალი ჩუენი, და ვინცა შეცვალოს, ცამ
ვთამცა(?) ვს წინაშე ღმრთისა.
item.note: On the feast of Enkenia, an agape was established for Grigol Mshvidai and his deceased relatives, with a liturgy by one priest. The foundation is protected by a powerful curse against any alteration, invoking excommunication and the wrath of the Trinity and the True Cross.
The entry emphasizes it was written with the consent of the entire monastic community, strengthening its authority.

item.p:
თუჱსა სეკდენბერსა იგ. აღაპი გაუ
ჩინეთ
ჩუენ, მამამან ჯუარისამან
ნიკიფორემ
და
ეპისკოპოზმან თეოდოსემ და ერთობილთა
ძმათა,
სეხნა მიქაძესა . მოგუცა ასი მარჩილი, და
ვინცა არ გარდაიჴადოს და დააკლოს, რის
ხავსმცა მამა, ძე და სული წმიდაჲ, ა{მი}ნ.
item.note: An agape was established for Sechna Mikadze by the monastery leadership (Father Nikifore, Bishop Teodose) and the brotherhood, in return for a donation of 100 marchili.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა იდ
ჯუარის ამაღლებასა დღესა წირვა და ჲღა
პი საუკუნო
მეფეთ მეფისა გიორგისი , შეუნდ
ვნეს ღმერთმან. თუ ორნიცა მოლაზონნი იყჳნენ,
არ დაკლდეს.
არქიმანდრიტმან მამამან ოსებ და
მოძღუარმან და სრულად
კრებულმან
გაუჩინეთ.
item.note: On the Feast of the Exaltation of the Cross, an eternal liturgy and agape were established for King of Kings Giorgi by the monastic leadership (Archimandrite Father Ioseb, the Teacher) and the full assembly. A special condition ensures the service is not diminished, even if performed by Laz monks.
King Giorgi, Archimandrite Ioseb, the Teacher.
The clause about Laz monks ('molazoni') is unusual and may reflect specific social or ecclesiastical dynamics of the period.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა იდ
ამასვე დღესა აღაპი
ივანე ქველ ივაჲსძისა შვი
ლისა ბასილისაჲ . ავიღეთ ათას შჳდასი დრამაჲ
მისისა ძმისა ტუღრნისა ჴელითა და სპარსთაგან
დაჭირულნი ლეღუნარნი ამა ოქროროჲთა (!) დავი
ჴსენით. ვიდრემდისცა ესე მონასტერი წესსა ზედა
ეგოს და შეუცვალოს შე-მცა-ცვალებულა სჯული
საგან ქრისტიანეთაჲსა.
item.note: An agape was established for Basili, son of Ivane Kvel Ivaysdze. The monastery received 1700 drama via Basili's brother Tughran, which was used to ransom fig orchards from the Persians during a time of distress. The foundation is protected by a curse of excommunication.
1700 drama received and used for ransoming property.
The entry records a direct interaction with Persians ('Sparsni') involving the ransom of monastic property (fig orchards).

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა იდ
ამანვე დღესა აღაპი და პანაშჳდი
ბაგრატ მე
ფისა , შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან.
item.note: Agape and requiem service established for King Bagrat.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა იდ
მოვიდა ნაუასძე ზოსიმე კუმურდოელი , მოი
ტანა საქონელი მისიცა და
პატრონის მისისა
ცა ქეთაონ-ყოფილისაჲ ქრისტინესი და
გულ
ქანისი . მას ჟამსა ფრანგთა გოლგოთაჲ წაგუ
ართუჱს და მან დაიჴსნა, ოთხასი ფლური გამო
იღო, დიდი საქმე ქნა, და ერთი კანდელი გოლ
გოთას და ერთი ჯუარს დაუკიდეთ სამუდამო. ვინ
მოშალოს, ღმერთმან მისი სული მოშალოს სა
სუფეველისაგან. პატრონსა ქრისტინეს შე
უნდვნეს ღმერთმან.
მისთჲ შვილთჲ იოთამს და
გულქანს შეუნდვნეს ღმერთმან.
ზოსიმე კუმურ
დოელსჲ და მისთა მიცვალებულთა ყოველ
თჲვე შეუნდვნეს ღმერთმან.
მისსჲ ხუცესსა იოსებს
შეუნდვნეს ღმერთმან.
item.note: Major foundation by Zosime of Kumurdo, who brought goods from himself and his patrons (Ketaon-Kristine, Gulqan) to ransom Golgotha from the Franks for 400 florins. In return, two perpetual candles were established, one at Golgotha and one at the Cross Monastery. The entry includes blessings for all involved parties.
Zosime Kumurdoeli (agent/donor), Ketaon-Kristine (patron), Gulqan (patron), Iotam (son), Ioseb (priest).
Records the loss and subsequent ransoming of Golgotha from the Franks ('Prangni'), a significant event in the history of the Holy Places.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა იე
მე მამა იოსებ და სრულა კრებულმან გაუ
ჩინეთ. მოვიდა კანდელაკის ჴელითა ას ოცი
ფული
აფაქის ძისა ჯავახისა და
მისის მეუღლის
ბორენისა , გაუჩინეთ მესმასა ზედა,
დიდდაჭირებისა ჟამსა მოგუეხმარა,
დიდუღობასა (?). ვინცა და რამანცა კაცმან,
რა ერთიცა მოლაზონი იპოებოდეს ჯუარისა
სახლსა შიგან, რამანცა ესე სალოცავი დააკლოს,
რჯულისამცა ქრისტიანობისა შეიცვალების, მათთ
მცა (!) გაიკითხვის.
item.note: Father Ioseb and the full monastic assembly established a memorial prayer to be read from the Mesma for Javakh Apakisdze and his wife Borena. They donated 120 'fuli' via the Kandelaki (candle-keeper) during a time of great need. A curse of excommunication is placed on anyone, even a Laz monk, who neglects this prayer.
Similar to Item 15, this entry specifically includes Laz monks ('molazoni') in its curse, suggesting a particular concern or dynamic.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა ივ
ამასვე დღესა წირვა და აღაპი საუკუნოჲ
ივ
ლიაჲს შვილისა მიქაელისა , შეუნდვენ ღმერთ
მან. ვინცა შეუცვალოს, კანონსამცა ქუჱშე არს.
item.note: An eternal liturgy and agape were established for Mikael, the son of Ivlia, protected by an ecclesiastical curse (canon).

p.persName:
ჯუარის პატიოსნისა ტრაპეზისა მეორედ
სრულობით აღმაშენებელსა და იოვანე მახა
რებლისა საყდრისა მეორედ აღმაშენებელსა, ამაღ
ლებელსა კუმურდოველსა სერაპიონს
p.seg:
შეუნდვნეს
ღმერთმან.

item.note: A memorial blessing for Serapion of Kumurdo, praised as the second builder of the altar of the Holy Cross Monastery and the second builder and exalter of the Church of John the Evangelist.
Highlights Serapion's role in rebuilding two significant religious structures.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა კ
ამასვე დღესა წირვაჲ და აღაპი საუკუნოჲ
ბექასა შვილისა შალვაჲსი , შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან.
item.note: An eternal liturgy and agape were established for Shalva, son of Beka.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა კვ
ამასვე დღესა წირვაჲ და აღაპი და პა
ნაშჳდი საუკუნოჲ
ამაშუკელისა ვაჩეს მეუღლისაჲ
ვანენისი . შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან.
item.note: An eternal liturgy, agape, and requiem were established for Vaneni, the wife of Vache Amashukeli.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა კდ
გაუჩინეთ ჩუენ, ჯუარის მამამან
ნიკიფო
რემ და სრულობით ერთობიილთ ძმათა, აღაპი
{ს}ულკურთხეულსა ზალლ ღოღაბერიძეს , და ვინც
დაკლოს, ღმერთმან იგი ლაკლოს წყალობისა
ღმთისაგან და რისხავმცა მამა, ძე და სული
წმიდაჲ, ა{მი}ნ.
item.note: Father Nikifore and the brotherhood established an agape for the 'soul-blessed' Zal Ghoghaberidze, protected by a curse invoking exclusion from divine mercy and the wrath of the Trinity.
The deceased is referred to as 'sulkurtkheuli' (soul-blessed), a title of respect.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა კდ
ამასვე დღესა აღაპი
თურგლა ბიჭილა
გიაისა მეუღლისა
ბორენაჲსი , რავდენიცა ხოცესი
იყოს ჟამის წირვითა, მოგუცა ათასი დრამაჲ.
ვინცა შეუცვალოს, შემცა-ცეალებულ არს შჯუ
ლისაგან ქრისტეანეთასა. საპანაშუიდეცა
მოგუცა ხუთასისა დრამისაჲ და ვინცა პანაშჳდსა
ცა არა გარდიჴდიდეს, ჰრისხვმცა მამა, ძე
და სული წ{მიდა}ჲ. მეორესა მოსულასა კუალადცა
შემოსწირეს ხუთასი თეთრი საპურედ, ღმერთმან
შეუნდვენ.
item.note: A major foundation by Borena, wife of Turgla Bichila Gia, establishing an agape and requiem, with a liturgy to be performed by all available priests. She donated 1000 drama for the main service and an additional 500 drama for the requiem. Later, she donated another 500 tetri for bread.
Total donation of 1500 drama and 500 tetri.
Service to be performed by all available priests, a mark of high honor.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა კვ
იოვანე მახარებ
ლისა დღესასწაულსა
წირვაჲ და აღაპი
მეფეთ მეფისა გიორგისი , საუკუნომცა არს
საჴსენებელი მათი, ა{მი}ნ.
item.note: On the feast day of St. John the Evangelist, a liturgy and agape were established for King of Kings Giorgi, with a blessing for his eternal memory.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა კვ
ამასვე დღესა აღაპი
თურგლა ბიჭილა გია
ნისაჲ . რაზომიცა ხუცესი იყოს, ჟამისი წირვი
თა. მოგუცა ათასი დრამაჲ. ვინცა შესცვალოს,
შე-მცა-ცვალებულ არს შჯულისაგან ქრისტე
ანეთასა, საპანაშუდეცა მოგჳცა ხუთასისა დრამი
საჲ და ვინცა პანაშჳდსაცა არ გარდიჴდიდეს,
ჰრისხავსმცა მამაჲ, ძე და წმიდაჲ სული.
item.note: On the same day as his wife's memorial (Item 25), Turgla Bichila Gia established his own agape and requiem, with a liturgy to be performed by all available priests. He donated 1000 drama for the main service and 500 drama for the requiem. The foundation is protected by curses of excommunication and Trinitarian wrath.
This entry appears to be a companion to Item 25, for the husband of Borena, with identical donation amounts and stipulations.

item.p:
სეკდენბერსა კვ
სეკდენბერსა კვ. წირვაჲ და აღაპი
ნათელ
დედოფალისაჲ , შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან.
item.note: Liturgy and agape established for Queen Natel.

item.p:
თუესა სეკდენბერსა ლ
ამასვე დღესა წირვაჲ და აღაპი საუკუნოჲ
შანშას ძმისა აღბუღაჲსი , შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან.
item.note: An eternal liturgy and agape were established for Aghbugha, the brother of Shansha.

item.p:
თუესა ოკდონბერსა ა
ამასვე დღესა წირვაჲ და აღაპი საუკუნოჲ
შანშაჲს ძმისა ვაჰრამისი , შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან.
item.note: An eternal liturgy and agape were established for Vahram, another brother of Shansha, on the following day.
This entry directly follows the memorial for his brother Aghbugha (Item 29), suggesting a coordinated family commemoration.

item.p:
თუესა ოკდონბერსა გ
ამასვე დღესა წირვაჲ და აღაპი საუკუნოჲ
ვარდან ფავნელისაჲ , შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან.
item.note: An eternal liturgy and agape were established for Vardan of Pavneli.

item.p:
თუესა ოკდონბერსა დ
ქ{რისტე}. ამასვე დღესა აღაპი
ამირეჯიბისა ზაქა
რიასჲ , ღმერთმან შეუნდვენ.
item.note: Agape meal established for Zakaria, the Amirejibi (high court official).

item.p:
თუესა ოკდონბერსა ე
ამასვე დღესა
გიორგი ხარაზისაჲ .
პანაშჳდი.
item.note: Requiem service for Giorgi the Shoemaker.

item.p:
თუესა ოკდონბერსა ვ
ამასვე დღესა წირვაჲ და აღაპი საუ
კუნოჲ
ძმისა ჩუენისა გიორგი ხარაზისაჲ .
შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან. და ვინცა შეცვალოს, შე
მცა-ცვალებულ არს შჯულისაგან
ქრისტეანე/თაჲსა.
item.note: An eternal liturgy and agape were established for "our brother" Giorgi the Shoemaker, protected by a curse of excommunication.
Referred to as "our brother", suggesting he was a member of the monastic community. This follows his requiem in the previous item.

item.p:
თუესა ოკდონბერსა ია
ამასვე დღესა პანაშჳდი არს
ძმისა ჩუენისა
ფილიპესი და ვინცა შეუცვალოს, კანუნსამცა
ქუეშე არს წმიდათა მოციქულთასა.
item.note: A requiem service was established for "our brother" Philipe, protected by the canon of the Holy Apostles.
The curse specifically invokes the authority of the canon of the Holy Apostles.

item.p:
თუესა ოკდონბერსა იზ
ამასვე დღესა აღაპი არს საუკუნოჲ პანა
შჳდითა
ფალგოზის ძისა მარუშიანისაჲ , ჯუარს
რაოდენიცა მწირველი იყოს, ჟამსა უწირ
ვიდეს. და ავიღეთ ათას ხუთასი დრამაჲ, ვინცა
და რამანცა კაცმან შეცვალოს და არ
გარდიჴადოს, შე-მცა-იცვალების სჯულისაგან
ქრისტეანეთაჲსა.
item.note: An eternal agape with requiem was established for Marushiani, son of Phalgozi. The monastery received 1500 drama for this foundation, which stipulates that all available priests at the Cross Monastery should celebrate the office. It is protected by a curse of excommunication.
Again stipulates the participation of all available priests, signifying high status or a substantial donation.

item.p:
თუესა ოკდონბერსა კა
ამასვე დღესა წირვა და აღაპი საუკუნო
ათაბაგისაჲ ყუარყუარეს შვილისაჲ ბადურისი ,
შეუნდვნეს ღმერთმან. მოგუივიდა ფ ფლული. და
ვინცა შეუცვალოს, ღმერთმან ჰკითხოს დაუსრუ
ლებელსა მას ცხორებასა.
item.note: An eternal liturgy and agape were established for Badur, son of Atabag Qvarqvare, for which 500 florins were received. The foundation is protected by a curse invoking divine judgment in the unending life.
Donation of 500 ('ფ' is a numerical letter for 500) florins.

item.p:
თუესა ოკდონბერსა კბ
ამასვე დღესა აღაპი
გიშელისა ლიპარიტი
სი , და შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან.
item.note: Agape meal established for Lipariti of Gishi.

item.p:
თუესა ოკდონბერსა კბ
ამასვე დღესა აღაპი
რუსუდანისი, კოსტან
ტინეს დედისაჲ , შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან.
item.note: Agape meal established for Rusudan, the mother of Konstantine.

item.p:
თუესა ოკდონბერსა კვ
ამასვე დღესა
მოსეს ძმისა გიორგისი
სა
წირავი ერთი ხუცესი.
item.note: A memorial liturgy to be celebrated by one priest was established for Giorgi, the brother of Mose.

item.p:
თუესა ოკდონბერსა კვ
ამასვე დღესა აღაპი
დემეტრე მეფისაჲ .
შეუცვალებელმცა არს უკუნისამდე.
item.note: An agape was established for King Demetre, with a declaration that it should be unchangeable forever.

item.p:
თუესა ოკდონბერსა კვ
ამასვე დღესა აღაპი და წირვაჲ
აბუსერის
ძისა ივანესი .
item.note: Agape and liturgy established for Ivane Abuserisdze.

item.p:
თუესა ოკდონბერსა კვ
ამასვე დღესა წირვა და აღაპა
სარ
გის ბოცოჲს ძის . მოგვივიდა ორას ორმო
ცი და თოთხმეტი ფლორი, შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან.
item.note: Liturgy and agape established for Sargis Botsosdze in return for a donation of 254 florins.

item.p:
თუესა ნოემბერსა ა
გაუჩინეთ ჩუენ ჯუარის მამამან
ნიკი
ფორემ
ჴელმწიფესა მეფესა გიორგის და
თანა
მეცხედრესა მისსა თამარ დედოფალსა
აღაპი
და დაუკიდეთ კანდელი და მოსახსენებილი
ეპისკოპოზმან თეოდოსემ და სრულად კრე
ბულთა
გჳჩინეთ ესე.
item.note: The monastery leadership (Father Nikifore, Bishop Teodose) and the entire assembly established an agape, a perpetual candle, and a memorial prayer for the Sovereign King Giorgi and his consort Queen Tamar.
King Giorgi, Queen Tamar, Nikifore (Cross Father), Teodose (Bishop).

item.p:
თუესა ნოენბერსა ა
ამასვე დღესა წირვაჲ და აღაპი და პანა
შუიდი საუკუნოჲ
ხაჟიკ ფალქოზის ძისა , შეიწყა
ლე ღმერთმან.
item.note: An eternal liturgy, agape, and requiem were established for Khazhik, son of Phalkozi.

item.p:
თუესა ნოემბერსა ბ
ამასვე დღესა აღაპი
გიორგი სულემანის
შვილისაჲ თფილელისაჲ . ვინცა შეუცვალოს,
შეი-მცა-იცვალების შჯულისაგან
ქრისაეანე/თაჲსა.
item.note: An agape was established for Giorgi, son of Suleman, from Tbilisi, protected by a curse of excommunication.

p.seg: შეუცვალებელი უკუნისამდე.

item.note: An agape was established for King Giorgi, declared to be unchangeable forever.

item.p:
თუესა ნოენბერსა ვ
ამასვე დღესა წირვაჲ და აღაპი საუკუ
ნოჲ
აფაქის ძისა მარუშიანისა , შეუნდვენ
ღმერთ/მან.
item.note: An eternal liturgy and agape were established for Marushiani, son of Apaki.

item.p:
თუესა ნოენბერსა ზ
ამასვე დღესა პანაშუდი
მიქაელ აფაქის
ძისა , შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან.
item.note: A requiem service was established for Mikael, son of Apaki.
Likely the brother of Marushiani from the preceding item, commemorated on the following day.

item.p:
თუესა ნოემბერსა ჱ
გაუჩინეთ ჩუენ მამამან ჯუარისამან
ნიკიფორემ კახმან ,
ეპისკოპოზმან თეოდოსემ ,
მარკოზ მღ{რ}დელ-მონაზონმან ,
აბრამ ,
ელიამ
იკონოსმან და სრულობით ძმათა კრებულთა
აღაპი
ჩიჩავაძესა ვახტანგს და
თანამეცხედრესა
მისსა მიქელაძისა ასულსა ხუჲრამზესა
და დიდე
ბულსა მიქაილ მთავარანგელოზისასა.
ყოველთა
წელთა დაუკლებელად გარდაიხდებოდეს და
ვინ
ცა ესე დაკლოს და არ გარდაიჴადოს, რისხავმცა
მამა, ძე და სული წმიდაჲ და
ამასრულებელ
ნი ამისნი ღმერთმან აკურთხნეს.
მოგუცა ასი მარჩილი და ერთი ბიჭი.
ჯუარის მამა და
სრულად კრებულნი ჟამსა სწირვიდენ.
item.note: On the feast of the Archangel Michael, the full monastic leadership established a perpetual agape for Vakhtang Chichavadze and his wife Khvyramze, daughter of a Mikeladze. They donated 100 marchili and a boy. The Father and the assembly are to celebrate the office.
Nikifore Kakhman, Teodose, Markoz, Abram, Elia the Ikonomos (donors/clergy); Vakhtang Chichavadze, Khvyramze Mikeladze (commemorated).
Donation of 100 marchili and one person (a boy).
The donation of a person ("bichi") reflects the social norms of the period.

item.p:
თუესა ნოემბერსა ჱ
ამასვე დღესა
მარინესი და
ბჲრბჲრესი ,
ღმერთმან შეუნდვნეს, ა{მი}ნ.
item.note: Memorial blessing for Marines and Byrbyres.

item.p:
თუესა ნოენბერსა ჱ
ამასვე დღესა წირვაჲ და აღაპი საუკუნოჲ
ბექასა შვილისა ყუარყუარესი , შეუნდვენ
ღმერთ/მან.
item.note: An eternal liturgy and agape were established for Qvarqvare, son of Beka.
Likely related to Shalva, son of Beka (Item 22).

item.p:
თუესა ნოემბერსა ჱ
ამასვე დღესა აღაპი
ანტონი ალავერდე
ლისაჲ , ვინ შეცვალოს შე-მცა-ცვალებულა წესის
აგან და სჯული ქრისტეანეთააჲსა.
item.note: An agape was established for Antoni, the Bishop of Alaverdi, protected by a curse of excommunication from the Christian rule and order.
Agape meal established for Photskhver, son of Tagdir.

item.p:
თუესა ნოენბერსა ი
ამასვე დღესა ნოენბერსა ი. გიორგიისა
დღესასწაოლსა
წირვა და აღაპი საუკუნოჲ
ჯუარის მტვირთველისა გერასიმესი
გარდაჲჴდებოდეს, შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან.
item.note: On the feast of St. George, an eternal liturgy and agape were to be celebrated for Gerasime, the Cross-bearer.
The title 'Juaris mtvirtveli' (Cross-bearer) indicates a specific and honored role in liturgical processions.

item.p:
თუესა ნოემბერსა ი
ამასვე დღესა ი. წმიდისა გიორგის
დღესასწაულსა
აღაპი სრული და ერთი ხუცე
სი უწირვიდეს
მარკოზეთ კჳრიკესთჳს , გარდა
იჴდებოდეს საუკუნო მიუკუნისამდე.
სახლი
აღაშენა, წაეგო ხუთასი დრამაჲ, მერმე აქაიას
საშენებლად მოგუცა მ ათი დრაჰკანი ,
ვინცა
შეუცვალოს ესე ჩუენგან განწესებული
საუკუნოჲ სალოცავი აღაპი, შე-მცა-ცვალე
ბულარს შჯულისაგან ქრისტეანეთაჲსა]
და მისთამცა ცოდვათა იგი ზღავს წინაშე
ღმრთისა.
ვინ დაამტკიცოს, კურთხეულ იყოს
უკუნისამდე.
item.note: On St. George's Day, a full agape and liturgy by one priest were established in perpetuity for Kvirike of the Markozeti family/place. He built a house at a cost of 500 drama and later gave 40+10 drahkani for building in Achaia. The foundation is protected by a strong curse and a blessing for fulfillers.
Cost of 500 drama for a house, plus a donation of 50 drahkani for building.

item.p:
თუესა ნოემბერსა ია-იბ
ამასვე დღესა აღაპი უნდა გარდაიჴდებო
დეს საუკუნო
კურთხეულის სფირიდონისთჳს და
მისისა მეუღლისა თინათინისთჳს , და
ვინცა მა
მაჲ იყოს და არ იქმოდეს, მისთჳსმცა ცოდვა
თაჲ მზღველი არის.
ასი ფლური ხაზინაშინგან
ჩაგჳცა და ერთო ვენაჴი ამბროსაულის თავსა
ვიყიდეთ და ერთი ბარძიმი გოლგოთას დავდ
გით ამა აღაპისთჳს.
item.note: An eternal agape was established for the "blessed" Spiridon and his wife Tinatin. For this, 100 florins were placed in the treasury, a vineyard was bought at Ambrosauli, and a chalice was placed at Golgotha. Any Father who neglects this service will be held accountable for their sins.
Donation of 100 florins, a vineyard, and a chalice.
The curse specifically targets the monastery's Father (abbot), placing personal responsibility on him.

item.p:
თუესა ნოემბერსა იბ
ქ{რისტე}. ნოენბერსა ათორმეტსა აღაპი
ზილაგია
ნისა ვახტანგისი , შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან.
item.note: Agape meal established for Vakhtang, of the Zilagiani family.

თუესა ნოემბერსა იბ
ამასვე დღესა აღაპი და პანაშჳდი საუკუნოჲ
ბეშქ{ე}ნ მანდატურთ უხუცესისა ვარდანის ძისა .

მისმან სიძემან ფურთუხ გარეყანის
ძემან
ორი ათასისა თეთრისა წითელი და გაუ
ჩინეთ აღაპი და პანაშჳდი, დაუკლებელად
გარდაიჴდებოდეს.
item.note: An eternal agape and requiem were established for Beshqen, son of Vardan, the Mandaturt-Ukhutsesi. His son-in-law, Phurtukh, son of Gareqani, donated 2000 red tetri for this service, which is to be performed without fail.

თუესა ნოენბერსა იგ

ივანე ქავთარისი .
ვინ არ გარდაიჴდიდეს-კრულმცა არს.
item.note: Agape established for Ivane Kavtarisi, with a curse on anyone who fails to perform it.

item.p:

ამასვე დღესა სრული აღაპი
ნიკოლოზის
შვილისა ქავთარისი . წააგო მონასტრისა სასაუ
რავოდ შჳდი ათასი დრამაჲ
დიდსა დაჭირება
სა ჩუენსა შინა მყოფთათჳს .
ვინ შეუცვა
ლოს, იოანე ოქროპირისა მიერ კრულმცა არს
item.note: A full agape was established for Kavtar, son of Nikoloz, who contributed 7000 drama for the provisions of the monastery during a time of great hardship. The foundation is protected by a curse from St. John Chrysostom.
The curse invokes the authority of a major Church Father, St. John Chrysostom.

ფილიპე გარეყანის ძი
სა , შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან.
item.note: Agape meal established for Philipe, son of Gareqani.
Possibly related to Phurtukh Gareqanisdze from Item 60.

ჯავეშიანისა ივა
ნესი , შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან.
item.note: Requiem service established for Ivane of the Javeshiani family.

item.p:
თუესა ნოენბერსა იდ
ამათ წმიდათა მარხვათა ქრისტეს
შობისათა და წმიდათა დიდთა მარხვათა
ყოველთა შაბათ-კჳრიაკეთა და ტაძრად მი
ყვანებასა, ხარებად და დიდსა ხუთშაბათსა
გაგჳჩენია ევაგრესი , რუსუდანესთჳს და თაყა ფა
ნასკერტელისთჳს, გავაჩინეთ
ჩუენ, ჯუა
რისა მამამან
სჳმო[ნ] ელმელიქის ძემან ,
მოძღუარმან აღდგომისამან ,
დეკანოზ
მან და იერუსალიმს და ჯუარს მყოფთა
ძმათა ერთსულობით .
გამოეგზავნა დიდსა
დაჭირებასა შიგაწ
დემეტრე მეფისა ასულ
სა რუსუდანს და
თაყა ფანასკერტელსა
შჳდიათასი
თეთრი და ამისთჳს მათთჳს სალო
ცავად.
რომე შემდგომად გამოწირვისა თჳთო
სეფისკუჱრი და თჳთოჲ სასუმელი ღჳნოჲ ერ
თობილსა კრებულსა მიეცემოდეს და მათ
თჳს შენდობასა იტყოდენ -- შაბათსა რუ
სუდანისთჳს და კჳრიაკესა თაყასთჳს.
და ათა
სი თეთრი სხუაჲ გამოეგზავნა მათვე საპა
ნაშჳდედ, რომე ტაძრად მიყვანებად რუ
სუდანისთჳს გარდაიჴდებოდეს და თევდო
რობად თაყასთჳს მისითა განგებითა.
და
ვინცა ესე გარდააგდოს რაჲსცა მიზეზი
სათჳს სადამდის ქართველნი იყვნენ, უნა
წილომცაა ქრისტესგან.
item.note: A major, complex foundation established by the entire monastic community for Rusudan (daughter of King Demetre) and Taqa Panaskerteli. In return for a donation of 7,000 tetri during a time of great hardship, a series of liturgies (Evagres) were established on major feasts and fasts. Additionally, a ritual offering of prosphora and wine was set for Saturdays (for Rusudan) and Sundays (for Taqa). A further 1,000 tetri was given for specific requiems. A curse disinherits any Georgian who neglects this foundation from Christ.
Rusudan (King Demetre's daughter), Taqa Panaskerteli, Svimon Elmelikisdze (Father), Aghdomisa (Teacher).
Includes a specified weekly ritual with prosphora and wine for the entire brotherhood, divided between the two benefactors on Saturday and Sunday.

ვარამის ცოლსა ესნა
თობს

ნისი იყო.
ასი ფლორი მოგუვიდა, შეუნდვენ
ღმერთმან.
item.note: A requiem service on Saturdays and Sundays was established for Esnatobs, wife of Varam, similar to the one for Rusudan (in Item 65), in return for a donation of 100 florins.
The entry explicitly references the ritual established in the previous item for Rusudan, indicating a model or template for such foundations.

item.note: An eternal agape was established for Gognia, brother of Khela, and for his wife Keklutsa.

item.note: An eternal liturgy and agape were established for Mzekal, daughter of Chila, with a special blessing to be recited from the Psalm "Cry Aloud" (ღაღადყავ, Ps. 141/142).
The entry specifies a particular liturgical text ('Ghadadqav') to be used for the blessing, a rare and specific instruction.

item.note: On the feast of the Presentation of the Theotokos, an eternal agape was established for Loma Dadian-Gurieli and his wife Adusajan.
The double title Dadiani-Gurieli signifies a powerful union of two major princely houses of Western Georgia.

ვინცა დააკლოს, ღმერთმან ჰკითხოს.

Likely the brother of Amira from the preceding item, as both are sons of a 'Gvirgen'/'Gurgen'.

ვარამისა

The term 'tsol-qopili' (former wife) suggests a separation or dissolution of the marriage before death, an interesting social detail.

იოსებ ქე
რიმადინისა შვილისა , შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან. და
მყოფელნი ამისნი და არა შემცვალებელნი ღმერთ
მან აკურთხნეს.
ჯორი გუიყიდა და სხუა სრული
სასყიდელი გამოიღოჲ.
item.note: An agape and liturgy were established for Ioseb, son of Qerimadini. He bought a mule for the monastery and provided another full payment. The entry includes a blessing for those who fulfill this duty.
Donation of a mule and an unspecified "full price".

item.p:
თუესა ნოემბერსა კე
მოგჳცა
ჩუენ მამასა ქერაბინს და
სრულად კრებულსა
ორნი ოთხთავნი და ბარ
ძიმი,
დაიჴსნა სპარსთაგან თორმეტ სომად და
ორმოც ფლურად.
გჳყიდა ოთხი ღარალა ხჳარ
ბალი, ერთი ჯორი, ერთი ვირი , ერთი აღაპი.
ნახევარი ღარალა ხურბალი წაჲგო და ძმათა და
დათა თეთრი გაგჳყო.
და გაუჩინეთ რომელნი
ქერობინთ ზედა დალოცვა.
ამისნი აღმასრუ
ლებელნი ღმერთმან აკურთხნეს.
item.note: Foundation record detailing multiple donations by Father Qerabin. He gave two tetraevangelia and a chalice, ransomed from the Persians for 12 'soma' and 40 florins. He also bought grain, a mule, a donkey, and established an agape. In return, a special blessing "Upon the Cherubim" was established for him.
Ransom of 12 soma and 40 florins; donation of grain, animals, and an agape.
A specific blessing, "Upon the Cherubim," was instituted, likely a reference to the Cherubic Hymn.

item.p:
თუესა ნოენბერსა კე
მე მამამჲნ იოსებ
ძელითა ცხოვრებისა
ვიყიდე საბაწმიდელთაგან ბარძიმი, ტა
ბაკი, საცეცხლური, ხჳვნი, კოვზი, სათბობი -- ყო
ლა ვერცხლისა თ ათას დრაჰკნად ...
ერთი აღაპი სრული და ძმათა და დათა შჳდ
შჳდი ვენეტიკური თეთრი.
და ჩუენ, კრებულ
მან, კანდელაკმან და მამამან, გაუჩინეთ და
ლოცვა უმეტესად ... ლარს ზედა , შეუნდვნეს
ღმერთმან.
item.note: Foundation by Father Ioseb, who purchased a complete set of silver liturgical vessels (chalice, paten, censer, etc.) from the monks of Mar Saba for 1000 drahkani. In return, a full agape was established, along with a distribution of 7 Venetian tetri to each brother and sister. The community established a special blessing for him.
Purchase of liturgical set for 1000 drahkani; distribution of Venetian tetri.
Records a significant transaction between the Cross Monastery and the Lavra of St. Sabas (Mar Saba).

item.p:
თუესა ნოენბერსა კგ
ამას დღესა აღაპი
სილხან ხუაშაქისა
გაზრდილისაჲ , მოსცა მონასტერსა ათას რვაასი
დრამაჲ, ვინცა შეცვალოს, კანონსა ქუეშე
იყავნ.
item.note: An agape was established for Silhan, the foster child of Khuashaqi, who gave the monastery 1800 drama. The foundation is protected by an ecclesiastical curse (canon).

This is the same Father Svimon who was a donor in Item 65.

item.note: An eternal liturgy and agape were established for Shalva, son of Shergil who was the son of Phalkozi.

'Velentiuri' likely refers to a type of Venetian currency.

item.note: A liturgy and agape were established by the monastic leadership for the family of Omani Cholaqasdze: Omani himself, his wife the nun Barbara, his son Kaikhosro, and his brother Iovane. The foundation is protected by a powerful curse invoking the Holy Sepulchre, the True Cross, and all the saints.
Omani Cholaqasdze, Barbara (nun, wife), Kaikhosro (son), Iovane (brother); Nikifore (Father), Teodose (Bishop), Mateoz (Priest-monk), Elia (Ikonomos) (clergy).

item.note: On the feast of St. Sabas, the full monastic leadership established a perpetual and inalienable agape for their patron Evdemon, son of Jaiani, a Tsalijikheli and formerly the Bishop of Dranda. The foundation is protected by a Trinitarian curse.
Evdemon (former Bishop of Dranda), Jaiani (father); Nikifore (Father), Teodose (Bishop), Papa Markoz, Papa Abram, Elia (Ikonomos) (clergy).
The term 'Drandel-qopili' indicates Evdemon was formerly the Bishop of Dranda but no longer held the position, an important detail of his life.

item.note: On the feast of St. Sabas, a liturgy and agape were established for Samadavle Makaridze. His former wife, Photine, donated 1000 drama. The service is to be held as long as the monastery exists and even one Georgian remains, with a reciprocal blessing for the fulfillers. The foundation was made by the monastic leadership, including Archimandrite Father Ioseb.
Samadavle Makaridze, Photine (former wife), Ioseb (Archimandrite), Giorgi (Teacher), Giorgi (Bishop of Chqondidi).

item.note: On St. Nicholas's day, the monastery leadership established an eternal agape for Keikhosro Tsulukidze. His benefactions included building the stone-vaulted Church of St. Nicholas near the Holy Sepulchre with 60 houses, and ransoming a mill and a vineyard. In return, the monastery painted his portrait, hung three perpetual candles (one before the portrait, one at the Holy Sepulchre, one at Golgotha), and inscribed his name in all memorial books. A powerful curse targets any person, including the Father, Patriarch, or Abbot, who would dare to abolish this foundation.
Keikhosro Tsulukidze (major benefactor), Nikifore Kakhman (Father), Teodose (Bishop), and other clergy.
Major construction and property ransoming project centered on the Church of St. Nicholas.
No monetary amounts, but implies significant expenditure for building and ransoming.

The entry outlines his ecclesiastical career: he was Bishop of Bedia before becoming Catholicos.

item.note: On his third visit, an eternal agape and requiem were established for Pirnatli, son of Qveli. He donated 2,200 drama. The service stipulates a liturgy by all available priests, who are to be paid from the church. The foundation is protected by a curse of excommunication and personal responsibility for the sins of the violator.
The memorial was established on the donor's third visit, a specific detail about his relationship with the monastery.

item.note: An agape was established for Basili, the Dean of Chqondidi, and for his parents, protected by a curse of eternal damnation.

item.note: On the feast of St. Spyridon, a liturgy and agape were established by the monastic leadership for Sarijan, son of Javakh, and his wife Tamar, daughter of Orbodzleli. The woman Khvarashan, later known as Photine, donated 1000 drama for this. The service is to be held as long as even two Georgians remain at the monastery, with a reciprocal blessing for those who fulfill it.
Sarijan Javakhisdze, Tamar Orbodzleli (commemorated); Khvarashan-Photine (donor); Ioseb (Archimandrite), Giorgi (Teacher), Giorgi (Bishop of Chqondidi) (clergy).
The donor Khvarashan took the religious name Photine.

item.note: On the same day (Feast of St. Spyridon), an eternal requiem (panashvidi) was established for Niania Amashukeli. It was stipulated that one priest should celebrate the liturgy for it.

item.note: By the help of God, the monk Pilipe arrived at the Holy Cross Monastery in Jerusalem. He brought a "Jerusalemite tetri" donation sent by Varazi, son of Surkhan, for the soul of his brother, Tamaz (who took the name Tadeoz). He entrusted to the monastery leadership a comprehensive donation which included cash, an endowment for a perpetual lamp at Golgotha, funds to redeem pledged liturgical vessels, various fees and payments to clergy and other monasteries, and funding for extensive repairs and furnishing of St. George's Church and other buildings. In response, the monastery community established a perpetual annual agape for the soul of Tamaz-Tadeoz to be celebrated every year on December 13th, with a blessing for its performers.
Tamaz-Tadeoz (commemorated), Varazi Surkhanisdze (donor), Pilipe (monk, agent), the monastic community of the Cross.

A large and itemized donation totaling over 150 florin, including: 100 florin primary donation; 32 florin for redeeming pledged items; 3 florin for registration; 2 florin to Katamon; 2 florin to the abbot; 4 florin to four priests (1 each); 3 florin for agapes; 2 florin to Shila; 1 florin (each) to other Georgian monasteries. Pilipe himself added 1 florin for a lamp at Shila, 4 florin for candles/incense, and 2.5 florin for oil at Golgotha. The donation also funded extensive construction and furnishing works.

The foundation included significant material contributions beyond cash: redeeming pledged liturgical vessels, extensive construction (whitewashing, door installation, plastering), and furnishing a church with curtains, lamps, and candlesticks.
The commemorated person, Tamaz, had taken the religious name Tadeoz.
The manuscript contains a scribal error, 'ფრურისა' (prurisa), which has been corrected to 'ფლურისა' (plurisa).

item.note: A liturgy and agape were established for Beshqen, son of Chila. For this, a donation of 1000 tetri was received from Aghbugha, son of Entelegi, delivered by the hand of Chiphkhuti, servant of the 'son of Chila'. The foundation is protected by a curse of excommunication.

item.note: A liturgy and agape were established for Lord Ioram, son of Spyridon. A donation of 100 florins was made for this perpetual agape, and another 100 florins for the lamp at Golgotha, given at a time of great decline. The record includes a blessing for those who fulfill it and a reciprocal curse for those who diminish it.
Total donation of 200 florins (100 for the agape, 100 for the lamp at Golgotha).
The donation was made during a time described as one of 'great decline' or impoverishment, highlighting its significance.

item.note: An eternal liturgy, agape, and prayer were established for the Prior Daniel. A donation was sent for this, including: 200 mutqali of gold for the agape fund; 60 mutqali to buy a vineyard for the nuns (who did not buy it and instead divided the money); and 10 somi for the priests (noted as a group gift, not per capita).
Prior Daniel (commemorated), the nuns, the priests.
Donation of 200 mutqali of gold, 60 mutqali, and 10 somi.
An interesting outcome is recorded: the 60 mutqali designated for a vineyard for the nuns was instead divided among them.
The scribe likely wrote 'მღრდელთათჳს' twice by mistake (dittography).

item.note: A requiem (panashvidi) was established for Arseni Chikhvareli, to be performed by one priest, following the same regulations set for the other (monastic) brothers. It is protected by a curse of eternal damnation.

item.note: A requiem (panashvidi) was established for Rusi, son of Chkheti. He donated 500 tetri during a time of great hardship, "when the Cross was turned against us." The service is to be fulfilled by one priest celebrating the liturgy, and anyone who fails to do so is subject to the canon.

The donation is specifically noted as having been made during a time of great trouble when the monastery itself was under threat ("the Cross was turned against us"), indicating a period of political or sectarian conflict.

item.note: A liturgy and eternal agape were established for Zaza of the Panaskerteli-Tsitsishvili family. The service is to be performed by all available priests, who should be paid for the offering from the monastery's funds. The foundation was established because a "great property" was received from him at a time when the monastery was in "great obligation" or difficulty.
An unspecified but "great" donation of property or goods.

The foundation was made in gratitude for a large donation received while the monastery was under a "great promise" or "great obligation/difficulty" (დიდს დაპირებაშიგან), highlighting the critical nature of the gift.

item.note: An eternal agape was established for Grigol Panaskerteli, who donated a property in Achaia, purchased for 800 drahkani, to the Cross Monastery. In return, the monastery established five agapes with requiems and liturgies for him per year, to be celebrated by all available priests, protected by a strong curse. The entry also records unrelated financial transactions on the same day: the distribution of 60,000 tetri among the Georgians in Jerusalem and a payment of 2,000 tetri to the Patriarch and his monasteries. A final blessing is given for the agents who handled the gold: Anton the Teacher, Mercha, and Vasaksi.
Donation of land valued at 800 drahkani. The entry also documents separate transactions totaling 62,000 tetri.
This record contains a separate financial account appended to the primary foundation charter, detailing the distribution of large sums of money on the same day.
The scribe made two apparent errors: 'წილიწადსა' for 'წელიწადსა', and 'მამასვე' for 'ამასვე'.

item.note: This is an addendum to Grigol Panaskerteli's foundation (item 123). It records that a second sum of 30,000 (currency unstated) was sent via Murvan. With this, the Achaia property was purchased for 24,000. The remainder was given for prayers/charity. A further 1,000 tetri was also sent via Anton.
Donations of 30,000 (unspecified currency) and 1,000 tetri. Expenditure of 24,000 for a land purchase.
This entry provides the financial details for the acquisition of the "Achaia property" mentioned in item 123.

item.note: The monastic community of the Cross, led by the abbot and teacher Pime, established a perpetual, never-extinguished lamp at the Tomb of Christ for the chief treasurer, Khelay. This foundation is protected by a reciprocal curse. The monastery bound itself to provide twelve litras of oil for it annually, without fail.
Khelay (Chief Treasurer, beneficiary), Pime (Abbot and Teacher, donor).
Monastery commits to an annual provision of 12 litras of oil.
This is an unusual record where the monastery acts as the patron, establishing an endowment for a lay official.
The scribe wrote 'ერითი' for 'ერთი' (one) and used the ambiguous term 'აღდგომილი', possibly meaning 'the one in charge'.

item.note: On Christmas Day, a liturgy, agape, and prayer were established for Makrine, formerly known as Shvenieri.
The commemorated person, Shvenieri, took the religious name Makrine.

item.note: On Christmas Day, an agape was established for Nikoloz Gulaberisdze. The monastery leadership decreed that wine from a vineyard he had redeemed should be used for his commemoration. The officiating priest for his service is to receive one litra of wine, and any remaining wine is for the monastery's use. The regulation is protected by a strong curse and a blessing. A final note refers to another document written by Nikoloz for details about what he "lost" or donated.
Donation/endowment of a vineyard. The priest officiating his memorial is to be paid one litra of wine.
The foundation is endowed not with money but with the produce of a specific vineyard, with detailed instructions for its use.

item.note: An agape and liturgy were established for Janibeg Zevdginidze. A donation of 200 florins was received for this. The service is to be celebrated by one priest, and a blessing is given for its performers. This entry provides the financial details for the memorial mentioned in item 128.
This entry appears to be a more detailed record of the same foundation mentioned in item 128, including the donation amount and ritual stipulation.

item.note: The monastic community, led by Pimen the Teacher and Oqropir the Kandelaki, established an eternal agape for Zakaria Panaskerteli and his sister, Marikh. Separately, Ripsime, the former wife of a Panaskerteli, donated two mashrabs (cups): one for the soul of Amighambar, and one for a toast to their son, Zakaria, to be used at the trapeza (refectory table). The end of the entry is illegible.
Zakaria Panaskerteli, Marikh Panaskerteli (commemorated); Ripsime (donor), Amighambar Panaskerteli (commemorated); Pimen (Teacher), Oqropir (Kandelaki) (monastic leadership).
This entry is related to items 105, 138, and likely others concerning the Panaskerteli family. Ripsime's husband is likely Amighambar, and their son is Zakaria.

იგი დააკლნეს, ამინ.
item.note: An agape was established for Melkisedek, King of Kings. The service is to be performed with liturgies by all available priests. It is protected by a reciprocal curse directed at any abbot or teacher who fails to fulfill it.

item.note: An agape was established for Arishiani, the Chief of Servants of Vardanisdze, Eristavi (Duke) of the Svans. He donated 1,500 tetri at a time of great hardship, when the Cross Monastery was held by the Persians and the monastic brotherhood was confined to the metochion (a monastic dependency). The donation is protected by a curse of excommunication.

This entry provides valuable historical context, noting that the donation was made during a period of Persian occupation of the monastery, a time of great distress for the Georgian monastic community.

item.note: At the vespers service of this day, a requiem was established for "our brother" Basili, who donated 500 tetri. The foundation is protected by a Trinitarian curse.

The scribe wrote 'ათისი' (athisi), likely an error for 'ათი' (ati, ten).

item.note: An eternal agape was established for a family: Sumbat Lasurisdze and his wife Nateli, and their son Ina and his wife Boba, with blessings for both couples.

item.note: On the feast of Theophany, an eternal liturgy and agape were established for Giorgi, King of Kings, with a formula affirming the eternity of his memory.
This is the second major feast day memorial for King Giorgi, the other being on Christmas (item 126).

item.note: An eternal agape was established for Inasar, son of Inasar, and his wife Agota. They donated 1,000 "Sortnoli" drama at the time when Sortan "gave us the Cross" (likely returned it to Georgian control). The foundation is protected by a strong curse of excommunication.
"Sortnoli" appears to be a specific type of drama, possibly named after the ruler Sortan mentioned in the same entry.
This donation is explicitly tied to a major historical event: the return of the Cross Monastery to the Georgians by a figure named Sortan.

item.note: An eternal liturgy and agape were established for the kandelakis (lamp-lighters) Nikodime, Mate, and Anton. They donated a vineyard located above the "Ambrosauli vineyard" to the Holy Cross Monastery. The service is to include a requiem and be celebrated by all available priests. The foundation is protected by a curse and a blessing.

item.note: An eternal liturgy and agape were established for Garsevan of the Irubakidze-Choloqashvili family. He sent a donation of 200 "Veleturi" florins. For 100 florins, an agape was established, and for the other 100, a lamp was hung at Golgotha. The foundation was made by the monastic community, led by Abbot Makare, who exhort their successors not to neglect the service.
Donation of 200 Veleturi florins, split between an agape fund and a lamp endowment.
"Veleturi" likely refers to florins minted in Velletri, Italy, or a similar type of high-quality European currency.

item.note: Ioane the Archbishop established an agape for Natel Dadiani, donating his own 1,000 tetri for the foundation. The service is to be celebrated by all priests present at the Cross Monastery and is protected by a curse of excommunication.

item.note: An agape was established for Father Prokhore. The prior is responsible for its fulfillment, which includes holding an all-night vigil and preparing a "good trapeza" (feast) for the monastic brothers.
This entry specifies a more elaborate ritual than usual, including a vigil and a full feast for the community.

This is almost certainly the same individual as in item 168, here specified with his title of "Teacher" (`მოძღვარი`).

item.note: An eternal agape for the soul was established for Patron Shuria. A donation of 101 mutqali of gold was given via Ivane Ksareshvili during a time of great straits and hardship from the Persians. An eternal, undiminished agape was established for him, to be held as long as the monastery exists, with the violator to be judged for his sins before God.
This donation was made during a period of hardship caused by Persians, similar to the context of item 145.
The scribe wrote 'სუსლსი' (suslsi), likely for 'სასულე' (sasule, for the soul), and 'გაიკითხვი' (gaikithkhvi) for 'განიკითხვის' (ganikithkhvis).

The name of the primary commemorated individual is damaged and partially illegible.

item.note: A liturgy and agape were established for the Queen of Queens, Makrine (formerly Shvenier). The entry notes that this is the anniversary of her death and includes a specific ritual instruction: an absolution is to be said for her during the elevation of the chalice.
The memorial includes a specific instruction for a prayer of absolution to be recited at the elevation of the chalice during the liturgy.
This is a detailed entry for the same individual mentioned in item 125, confirming her religious name, royal title, and date of death.

item.note: The monastic community, led by Abbot Nikiphore, established a full liturgy and agape for Lord Otia, son of the Gurieli. The ritual stipulates that all priests, deacons, and monks should perform prostrations. The foundation is protected by a strong curse invoking the Holy Trinity and all the saints.
Lord Otia, son of Gurieli (beneficiary); Abbot Nikiphore (donor).
This is another case where the monastery acts as the patron, establishing a memorial for a lay noble.

item.note: On the feast of the Presentation of Jesus, a liturgy and agape were established for Davit, King of Kings. This was done at the time when he sent 1,200 mutqali of gold, which saved the monastery from great debt. A second liturgy and agape were established for him on Easter for the same reason. His perpetual commemoration includes prayers at the elevation of the Holy Gifts and upon entering the refectory. This is to be done without fail, even if only one Georgian remains.
The donation is explicitly stated to have saved the monastery from a great debt, leading to the establishment of two major feast day memorials and other perpetual prayers.

The foundation is protected by an incomplete curse of excommunication and vicarious liability for the violator's sins.
The nobleman Javakhi Toreli took the monastic name Sumeon.

item.note: On the feast of the Annunciation, an agape and requiem were established for the King of Kings, Vakhtang, and his wife, Ripsime. All priests and deacons are to be vested for the service, and the abbot is to provide the offering. A reciprocal blessing is given for its performers. This record also notes that at the time when the monastery was taken by the Persians for 26 years, the abbots Solomon and Svimeon contributed eight "heads of Lahri" and 1,000 tetri to the monastery.
King Vakhtang, Queen Ripsime (commemorated); Abbot Solomon, Svimeon (donors).
A donation from the abbots of 8 "Lahri" (a type of textile or good) and 1,000 tetri.
The entry connects the memorial to a past donation made by the monastery's leadership during a 26-year period of Persian occupation.

item.note: A second donation was received from Makrine (formerly Shvenier): 74 somi and 290 mutqali of gold. In response, the monastic community, led by Abbot Ioseb and the kandelaki, established an enhanced blessing for her to be recited during the "Blessed is...", the Gospel reading, and the "Magnify..." parts of the liturgy.
Donation of 74 somi and 290 mutqali of gold.
The foundation specifies prayers at three distinct points in the liturgy, an unusually detailed instruction.
This is a major addition to the memorials for Queen Shvenier-Makrine, also mentioned in items 125 and 180.

item.note: The abbot and the entire monastic community established a commemoration for Lady Marekh. It is to be performed by the priest after the clergy have taken communion and are elevating the Holy Gifts, at which point the priest shall proclaim: "May God forgive Marekh, Amen."
This entry contains a very specific instruction for a verbal proclamation by the priest during the liturgy.

item.note: In the name of God, Marine (formerly Mamqan), daughter of the Tmogveli-Ujarmeli, a humble nun, undertook the construction of a tower in the wall of the Holy Cross Monastery on the fathers' side. She gave 60 florins for the salvation of her sinful soul. The entry concludes with a personal prayer to the Holy Cross to have mercy on the souls of her husband, Thaqa Panaskerteli, herself (Marine), her brother Roin, and their parents.
Mamqan-Marine (donor and commemorated), Thaqa Panaskerteli (husband), Roin (brother), their parents.
Donation of 60 florins to fund the construction of a tower.
The donor, Mamqan, took the religious name Marine.

item.note: An agape was established for Giorgi Mozdodiani, who donated 1,000 drama for a perpetual agape fund at the Cross Monastery. A curse of excommunication is placed upon anyone who fails to perform the service as long as the monastery stands in its rite.

item.note: On St. George's Day, an agape and requiem are held for Giorgi Dadiani, Eristavi of Eristavis. The context seems to indicate he greatly [helped] the monastery. The entry is protected by a curse and a blessing.
No amounts specified, though a significant donation is implied.

item.note: An eternal agape was established for Giorgi, King of Kings, on St. George's Day (April 23), for which a donation of 100 florins was received. A "well-received" agape with a liturgy is to be held, as surely as a cartwheel turns downhill. This is never to be diminished as long as the monastery exists. The entry is protected by a curse and a blessing.
The scribe wrote 'ფლულრი' for 'ფლური' (florin) and used a colloquialism 'დაღმა მოვიდოდეთ' (to go downhill) to express certainty or perpetuity.

item.note: Ripsime (formerly Roadam), daughter of Thaqay Amilakhori and a humble nun, recounts her pious works. She bought a property called "Magh...rita" that had been sold. When it was being demolished for its stones, she bought it a second time to save it. The mill on the property was in ruins, and she rebuilt it with a new wheel and stone, and then offered it to the Holy Cross Monastery. In return, she established an eternal agape and liturgy, funded by the new wine (majari), for herself, her "spiritual daughter" Tekla, her parents, her husband, and her son.
Ripsime-Roadam (donor), Tekla (spiritual daughter), her parents, her husband, her son.
Donation of a rebuilt mill and its property, which she had purchased twice to save from destruction.
The donor, Roadam, took the religious name Ripsime.

Donation of one set of vestments.

item.note: A payment was received from Atabagi Ivane for his Orthodox soldiers who were wounded by the Turks on the third of the month of Kvirikoba (July). In response, the monastic community, led by Abbot Pimen, established a blessing for them, with an exhortation not to neglect it.
Atabagi Ivane (donor), his wounded soldiers (commemorated), Abbot Pimen.
This entry commemorates a specific historical event: a battle with the Turks on July 3rd.

გაუჩინეთ , შეუნდვენ ღმერთმან.
item.note: This entry records the donation for the memorial in the preceding item: 400 mutqali of gold was received from Amira, son of Tagdiri. In return, a prayer was established for him during the 'mesmasa' part of the liturgy.
A prayer was established during a specific part of the liturgy known as 'mesmasa'.

item.note: A donation was received from Markoz, Bishop of Bedia, consisting of 20 somi, 10 tanga, 10 florins, and two silver belts. In return, a blessing was established for him during the 'mesma' part of the liturgy, with a blessing for its performers.
Donation of 20 somi, 10 tanga, 10 florins, and two silver belts.

item.note: An agape was established for Makharebeli and Svimon, who donated 1,000 drama. The service stipulates that one priest should celebrate a liturgy for each of them individually, followed by a full agape for both together. The foundation is protected by the canon.

item.note: A requiem was established for Arseni Tsontsurikaytisi, to be celebrated by one priest. The ritual includes a distribution of bread (p'ori) and 'dgnopi' to the brothers, and a blessing of the eulogia bread. He donated four liturgical books to the church: one Four Gospels (Otkhtavi), one Book of Prophets, one Lenten Triodion (Markhvani), and one Paschal book (Zatikni). The foundation is protected by a curse of vicarious liability for the violator's faults and by the canon.
Donation of four significant liturgical books.
This entry describes a complex ritual involving the distribution of specific foods ('p'ori' and 'dgnopi', the latter being of unclear meaning) and blessings.

item.note: An agape and requiem were established for Konstantine, King of Kings of the Abkhazians, who is described as the "new adornner" of the Cross Monastery. The service is to be held undiminished, with an all-night vigil and a priest's liturgy.
King Konstantine is honored with the title "new adornner of the Cross Monastery," indicating he was a major benefactor or renovator.

The donor, Sula, took the religious name Serapion.

item.note: A prayer for Lord Giorgi Dadiani and his children. An agent sent by them, Makharebeli of Jikheti, stayed at the Cross Monastery for one year and presented a donation of a golden necklace and two somi. In return, a blessing was established for the Dadiani family to be recited during the Gospel and Synaxarion readings. The foundation is protected by a curse of vicarious liability for the violator's sins.
Patron Giorgi Dadiani and his children (beneficiaries); Makharebeli of Jikheti (agent).
Donation of a golden necklace and two somi.
The foundation specifies prayers to be said at two key points in the service: during the Gospel reading and the Synaxarion reading.

item.note: The same woman from the preceding entry, Makrine (formerly Mariam), daughter of the Gurieli, presented 2,000 tetri to the Holy Cross Monastery. The community established a prayer for her: during the liturgy, before the "Blessed is...", the priest is to say aloud, "May God forgive Makrine, formerly Mariam." The foundation is protected by a curse.
The foundation specifies the exact wording of a prayer and the precise moment in the liturgy when it should be recited.

item.note: The monastic community, led by Abbot Nikiphore, established an agape for the "blessed" Lady Khvaramze, daughter of Dadiani and wife of Gobidze. She donated 500 marchili. The service is to be a "well-received" agape with a liturgy celebrated by all available priests and the abbot himself. Additionally, a perpetual lamp was hung for her soul. The foundation is protected by a strong curse invoking the Trinity and holding the violator liable for her sins.
Lady Khvaramze Dadiani (donor), Gobidze (husband), Abbot Nikiphore.

item.note: An agape and vigil were established for "our venerable father and martyr," Luka, who was martyred for the sake of the monastery. His service is to be performed undiminished, like that of the other holy martyrs, so that God may make us complete through his intercession.

item.note: The monastic community, led by Abbot Nikiphore, established a "well-received" agape for the lady and queen, Mariam, Queen of Kartli. All priests and deacons are to celebrate the liturgy and perform prostrations for her. The foundation is protected by a strong Trinitarian curse.
Queen Mariam of Kartli (beneficiary), Abbot Nikiphore (donor).

item.note: A liturgy and agape were established for Patron Qurqure, Atabagi-Amirspasalar. For this, a 'dari' (type of property) adjacent to 'Ivane's dari' was purchased, which yields an income of 7 florins per year to fund the agape. Additionally, a chalice, plate, 'kamara' (vessel cover), and spoon were purchased for 27 florins and placed at the Cross Monastery for his soul. These actions were carried out by his agents, Athanase the Teacher of Bana, and Jalal Giorgi the Mestumre (royal host). The foundation is protected by a curse.
Patron Qurqure (Atabagi-Amirspasalar); Athanase (Teacher of Bana) and Jalal Giorgi (Mestumre) as agents.
Donation of a property with an annual income of 7 florins, and a set of liturgical vessels valued at 27 florins.

item.note: A liturgy, celebrated by one priest, was established for Martha, the sister of Guarandukht. The officiating priest is to be given bread to eat and a payment from the church. The service is to be held as long as the monastery exists.
Payment of bread and an unspecified fee to the officiating priest.

item.note: An eternal liturgy and agape were established for "our" Iskandar, son of Aghabega. This was done because at a time of great hardship, when the monastery's vineyard and all its liturgical vessels were held in pledge (amanat), he redeemed them by spending 800 ducats. In return, the community, led by Abbot Epiphane, established an undiminished agape, a feast for the brothers, and liturgies by all priests. They also hung two perpetual lamps for him: one at the fissure of the rock of Golgotha, and one before the "eye" of the True Cross. The service is to be held even if only two Georgians remain.
Iskandar, son of Aghabega (donor); Abbot Epiphane.
Donation of 800 ducats to redeem the monastery's vineyard and liturgical vessels from pledge.

This entry details a critical moment in the monastery's history, when it was in such dire straits that its core assets were pledged as security for a debt. Iskandar's donation is presented as a salvation of the monastery itself.

item.note: An eternal agape, with one priest, was established for Rusudan, daughter of Guirguina. She donated 1,200 drama to the monastery for one priest to celebrate a liturgy for her in her own church every year during Great Lent. She gave another 1,400 drama so that the officiating priest would be paid for the liturgy. The foundation is protected by a curse of excommunication and vicarious liability for sins.
Total donation of 2,600 drama (1,200 for a service in her own church, and 1,400 for payment to the priests at the monastery).

item.note: An agape was established for Aghbugha, grandson of Shanshe. The foundation was made by Burena, the wife of Quarquare. The entry includes blessings for the commemorated and for the performers of the service.
Aghbugha (grandson of Shanshe); Burena (wife of Quarquare) as donor.

item.note: This day commemorates the martyrdom of Salome the Georgian. At first she erred by the hand of the Persians and denied Christ, but afterwards she confessed the faith of Christ again. She was beheaded, and her martyrdom was completed by fire.

item.note: An agape was established for Arseni the Teacher, to be performed in full with liturgy and all related works. He donated ninety-seven 'Suruli drahkani' during a time of great hardship. The foundation is protected by a curse of excommunication and vicarious liability for the donor's sins.
'Suruli' may refer to currency from Tyre (Sur) or a similar specification.

item.note: An agape, requiem, and liturgy were established for the family of Aphaqisdze the Ejibi (Chamberlain), his wife Nebismqopeli, and their son. For their souls, a donation of 24 florins and 15 households ('kuamli katsi') was recorded.
Aphaqisdze the Ejibi, Nebismqopeli (wife), their son.
Donation of 24 florins and 15 peasant households.

The entry "Qristina-yopilisa Qristinisi" suggests a name change, but it is unusual for both names to be the same.

item.note: A memorial was established for Anusia (formerly Shveniere), daughter of Makarisdze, and her husband Maqa of Vardzia. Whenever the liturgy is celebrated in August, a requiem is to be held for them. The entry notes that they rebuilt the 'Maghribi' (a western part of the monastery or a dependency) for a second time.
No amounts specified, but the rebuilding of a significant property is noted.
The commemorated woman, Shveniere, took the religious name Anusia.

item.note: On the feast of the Transfiguration, a liturgy and agape were established for King Davit. The entry reiterates that this was done at the time when his donation of 1,200 mutqali of gold saved the monastery from debt.
Donation of 1,200 mutqali of gold is recalled.
This entry explicitly links the Transfiguration memorial to the major donation by King Davit detailed in item 196.

item.note: An eternal agape was established for Anasughli. He donated 130 ducats, and then commissioned a cross for 80 ducats which he placed on the altar. Subsequently, the King of Jerusalem became angry with the monastery, seized its property, and demanded gold. In this time of great need, Anasughli provided another 100 ducats. In return, the community decreed that the officiating priest and all deacons should bless him and his son Iaghi by name at every liturgy, as long as the monastery exists. The foundation is protected by a strong curse.
Anasughli (donor), Iaghi (his son), the King of Jerusalem.
Total donation of 230 ducats, plus an 80-ducat cross.
This entry documents a major crisis in the monastery's relationship with the local Crusader authorities, and a significant intervention by a benefactor.

item.note: The Abbot of the Cross, Nikiphore, established an agape for Lady Darejan, daughter of the Dadiani, and her mother Tinatin the Gamdeli. All priests and deacons are to celebrate the liturgy and perform a "well-received" agape. The foundation is protected by a strong curse invoking the Trinity and all the saints.

An unspecified but "full" payment was received for the endowment.

item.note: An eternal liturgy and agape were established for Davit, King of Kings and "Second Founder" of the holy monastery. He is celebrated for having restored the monastery and church, which had been seized by the Saracens and converted into a mosque, to the Georgian people for worship. The entry includes a prayer for his eternal memory and a reciprocal curse against any who neglect the service.
No amounts specified, but a major restoration is described.
This is a highly significant entry detailing King Davit's role in reclaiming the monastery from Saracen control after its conversion to a mosque.

item.note: An eternal agape was established for Daniel, Catholicos of Abkhazia, and his son Giorgi, Bishop of Chqondidi. A full agape and commemoration fund was received, with which the community was satisfied. Their service is to be held on August 17, on the feast of 'Satphureba' in Armasia. They are also to be remembered daily during the reading of the Synaxarion. The entry includes an entreaty not to neglect the service.
Daniel (Catholicos of Abkhazia), Giorgi (Bishop of Chqondidi, his son).
A "full" agape and commemoration fund was received.
'Satphureba' is likely a local name for a feast of the Theotokos.

item.note: A liturgy and agape were established for Lord Ioram, son of Spiridon, with a prayer for his eternal memory. An unspecified amount of florins was received from him for this agape. The entry is damaged but seems to mention further endowments for the Cross Monastery and Golgotha.

This is the same individual as in item 114, where a donation of 200 florins is recorded.

item.note: An agape was established for Abed ebnu Sururi, and a requiem and liturgy for Salim. Abed donated his house in Ramla to serve as a metochion (monastic dependency). The services are for the benefit of his parents and his wife. The foundation is protected by a formula stating that God will question anyone who alters it.
Abed ebnu Sururi (donor), Salim, Abed's parents and wife (commemorated).
Donation of a house in Ramla.

ობად
გამიჩინა.

item.note: This is a follow-up exhortation, likely from the donor Abed ebnu Sururi of the preceding item. He states that he has established these agapes as a vow of brotherhood and charges the abbot and Georgians of the monastery to perform them without fail.

item.note: Zosime the Teacher attests that he is a witness to the command of the abbot and the brothers regarding the preceding foundation.

item.note: An agape was established for Ivane, brother of the Eristavi of Kartli, protected by a curse of eternal damnation.
Ivane, brother of the Eristavi of Kartli.

item.note: An eternal agape with liturgy was established for Shalva Khuturisdze, the Mestumre (royal host), to be performed undiminished. The foundation is protected by a curse of excommunication and vicarious liability for sins before God in the world to come.

item.note: On the feast of the Beheading of John the Baptist, an agape and requiem were established for Giorgi Dadiani.

item.note: On the Sunday of the Publican and the Pharisee, an agape was established for Davit, son of Ardashel, and his wife Khuarashan. They donated 1,000 drama during a time of great hardship. The service is to be held as long as the monastery exists and is protected by a curse of excommunication.
This service is tied to a moveable feast, the Sunday of the Publican and the Pharisee, which marks the beginning of the pre-Lenten season.

item.note: On Cheesefare Sunday, an eternal agape, liturgy, and requiem were established for Grigol, Bishop of Dranda. The entry includes a blessing for performers and a curse of vicarious liability under the canon for those who neglect it.
This service is tied to a moveable feast, Cheesefare Sunday (the last Sunday before Great Lent).

item.note: Borena established an eternal requiem for the deceased sons of Gobo: Zviadi, Iovane, Keche, Beshqen, and Sargis. The requiem is to be held at vespers on Friday of Cheesefare Week. On the following Saturday, one priest is to celebrate a liturgy for each of the five men, with payment for the offerings to be given from the church. Borena donated 600 tetri for this. The foundation is protected by a curse of excommunication and by the grace of the Holy Sepulchre.
Zviadi, Iovane, Keche, Beshqen, Sargis (the sons of Gobo, commemorated); Borena (donor).
This service is tied to a moveable feast, Friday of Cheesefare Week.

item.note: On the third week of Lent, an undiminished agape with liturgy is to be held for Patron Orzhanda. A donation of 100 florins was received for this service, which is to be held on the third Saturday of Lent. The entry includes a curse for violators and an exhortation not to neglect the agape.
This service is tied to a moveable feast, the third week of Great Lent.

item.note: On this day (third Sunday of Lent), an agape and liturgy were established for Patron Atabagi Kaikhosro. He purchased a field for 100 florins, for which this service was established. It is protected by a curse.
This service is tied to a moveable feast, the third Sunday of Great Lent.
Donation of a field purchased for 100 florins.

item.note: On the third Sunday of Lent, an eternal agape and liturgy were established for Beka, the Mandaturt-ukhutsesi.
This service is tied to a moveable feast, the third Sunday of Great Lent.

item.note: On the fifth Saturday of Lent, an eternal agape with a liturgy by one priest was established for Mikael of Kvabiskhevi. It is protected by the canon of the holy apostles.
This service is tied to a moveable feast, the fifth Saturday of Great Lent.

item.note: On Tuesday of Holy Week, an agape was established for Saghir, son of Lashkhay, protected by the canon of the holy apostles.
This service is tied to a moveable feast, Tuesday of Holy Week.

item.note: On Holy Saturday, an eternal agape was established for Qondo, son of Chakhobi. He donated 1,000 tetri via the hand of Tevdore. The foundation is protected by the canon of the holy apostles.
This service is tied to a moveable feast, Holy Saturday.

item.note: On the Third Sunday (of Easter), an eternal requiem was established for Ioseb, son of Khavtay, with a blessing for its performers.
This service is tied to a moveable feast, likely the Third Sunday of Easter (Sunday of the Myrrh-bearing Women), though "Third Sunday" could also refer to Thomas Sunday (the second).

item.note: On the 6th Wednesday (after Easter), an agape was established for Tamar, daughter of Unghul, son of Mamlaqan. The foundation is protected by a strong curse and a blessing.
This service is tied to a moveable feast, the sixth Wednesday of the Paschal season.

item.note: On the 7th Saturday (after Easter), an agape was recorded, but the entry is now faded and only individual words are legible.
This service is tied to a moveable feast, the seventh Saturday of the Paschal season.

item.note: On the Monday of the Holy Spirit (day after Pentecost), an agape was established for Shota, the Mechurchlet-ukhutsesi (Master of the Royal Cellars/Treasury), protected by a curse of excommunication.
This service is tied to a moveable feast, the Monday after Pentecost.

item.note: On the Sunday of All Saints, an agape with a liturgy celebrated by one priest was established for Dzagani, son of Abuleti. It is protected by the canon of the holy apostles.
This service is tied to a moveable feast, the Sunday of All Saints (the first Sunday after Pentecost).
